question: [File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 77-84] [Information Disclosure] Does LATEST_PROCESSED_VERSION expose the exact blockchain version being indexed, allowing attackers to determine which transactions have been processed and potentially time attacks based on indexing lag? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 11-18] [Information Disclosure] Does PROCESSOR_INVOCATIONS expose internal processor names and invocation patterns, allowing attackers to fingerprint the indexer configuration and identify high-value processing targets for attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 21-28] [Information Disclosure] Does PROCESSOR_ERRORS expose which specific processors are failing, allowing attackers to identify weak points in the indexing pipeline and focus attacks on vulnerable processors? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 41-47] [Information Disclosure] Does UNABLE_TO_GET_CONNECTION reveal database connection pool configuration and capacity limits, allowing attackers to calibrate connection exhaustion attacks precisely? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 59-65] [Information Disclosure] Does UNABLE_TO_FETCH_TRANSACTION expose transaction fetch failure patterns that could reveal network topology or node synchronization issues attackers could exploit? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 77-84] [State Inconsistency] Can LATEST_PROCESSED_VERSION be set to values that don't match the actual database state if processors update metrics but fail to commit transactions, causing monitoring to show incorrect indexing progress? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 31-38 + 21-28] [State Inconsistency] Can PROCESSOR_SUCCESSES be incremented while PROCESSOR_ERRORS is also incremented for the same transaction batch, creating contradictory metrics that hide actual processing failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 11-18 + 31-38] [State Inconsistency] Can the ratio of PROCESSOR_INVOCATIONS to PROCESSOR_SUCCESSES become inconsistent if processors crash mid-execution, preventing accurate calculation of success rates and hiding processor reliability issues? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 50-56 + 41-47] [State Inconsistency] Can GOT_CONNECTION and UNABLE_TO_GET_CONNECTION counters become desynchronized with actual connection pool state if connections are leaked or not properly tracked, hiding resource leaks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 68-74 + 59-65] [State Inconsistency] Can FETCHED_TRANSACTION and UNABLE_TO_FETCH_TRANSACTION counters diverge from actual transaction fetch counts if retries are not properly tracked, causing incorrect availability metrics? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 11-18] [Resource Exhaustion] Can unbounded growth of PROCESSOR_INVOCATIONS metric labels cause memory exhaustion if new processors are dynamically created without cleanup, leading to indexer crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 21-28] [Resource Exhaustion] Can excessive error rates causing rapid PROCESSOR_ERRORS increments lead to memory exhaustion in the Prometheus client's internal buffers, causing metrics export failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 77-84] [Resource Exhaustion] Can creating hundreds of processor instances with unique names cause LATEST_PROCESSED_VERSION gauge to allocate excessive memory for label storage, leading to OOM crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 1-84] [Memory Leak] Are metric instances properly cleaned up when processors are stopped, or do Lazy-initialized metrics leak memory over time as processors are created and destroyed during reconfiguration? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 11-18] [Missing Validation] Is there any validation of processor_name label values in PROCESSOR_INVOCATIONS, or can empty strings, null bytes, or excessively long names cause metric registration failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 77-84] [Missing Validation] Is there any validation that LATEST_PROCESSED_VERSION values are monotonically increasing, or can processors set arbitrary version numbers causing version tracking to become unreliable? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 77-84] [Missing Validation] Can LATEST_PROCESSED_VERSION be set to negative values (valid for i64) causing version tracking to break and potentially allowing replay of already-processed transactions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 11-84] [Error Handling] Do metric registration failures from unwrap() calls get logged anywhere, or do they silently crash the process without providing debugging information about the metric registration failure cause? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 77-84] [Timing Attack] Can an attacker observe LATEST_PROCESSED_VERSION updates through the metrics endpoint to determine exactly when specific high-value transactions are being indexed, enabling timing attacks on concurrent operations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 21-28] [Timing Attack] Can monitoring PROCESSOR_ERRORS rate changes reveal when specific transaction types or patterns cause processing failures, allowing attackers to identify exploitable transaction structures? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 41-47] [Side Channel] Can timing the rate of UNABLE_TO_GET_CONNECTION increments reveal database connection pool capacity and utilization patterns, enabling attackers to optimize connection exhaustion attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 11-18] [DoS] Can an attacker trigger rapid processor invocations to increment PROCESSOR_INVOCATIONS at extreme rates, causing CPU exhaustion in the Prometheus client's metric aggregation logic? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 21-28] [DoS] Can deliberately causing processors to fail repeatedly to increment PROCESSOR_ERRORS consume excessive CPU/memory in metric tracking, degrading overall indexer performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 77-84] [DoS] Can rapidly setting LATEST_PROCESSED_VERSION from multiple processors cause contention on the gauge's internal locks, degrading processing performance across all processors? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/counters.rs] [Lines: 1-84] [DoS] Can scraping the metrics endpoint with high frequency cause CPU exhaustion as all counters and gauges are serialized and exported, enabling DoS of the indexer monitoring? (Low)
